oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Parenteral nutrition in cattle
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Divers, Thomas J.
Sweeney, Raymond W.
Galligan, David
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: calf diseases
calves
Diarrhoea
Fluid therapy
Parenteral feeding
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The use of parenatal nutrition was studied in 32 calves suffering from calfhood diseases that required nutritional support. The most frequent clinical condition requiring parenteral nutrition was a chronic diarrhea and wasting syndrome seen in 20 of the calves. An amino acid-dextrose solution (Formula I) was administered to 27 calves and an amino acid-dextrose-lipid solution (Formula II) was administered to 5 calves. Enteral feeding was limited to less than one-half of the normal requirements for the sick calves. The combination of limited milk and parenteral nutrition using Formula I or II supplied more than 100 percent of the energy and protein requirements for a healthy calf.
